Posts.Content: YamaMama wrote: A friend sent me this info today....so I'm passing it along to you all. Cleaning for a Reason If you know any woman currently undergoing Chemo, please pass the word to her  that there is a cleaning service that provides FREE housecleaning - 1 time per month for 4 months while she is in treatment. All she has to do is sign up and have her doctor fax a note confirming the treatment. Cleaning for a Reason will have a participating maid service in her zip code area arrange for the service. http://www.cleaningforareason.org I don't know anything about this company or service...so I can't vouche for it. But here it is for you. Dx 5/1/2009, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2012 04:21PM YamaMama wrote: Ok, so I responded with others to this article last night. But it continues to irritate me.  There is an area above the article to email the author. Here's my email: Your article How Surviving Breast Cancer Changed Me, is filled with incorrect and even cruel information. Please contact a reliable site such as the Metastatic Breast Cancer Network for true stats. A site that is not trying to pinkwash everything.  I am very sad for the women who will believe they can't or won't eventually be stage IV, and who believe there is a cure, due to misleading articles such as yours. This comment is from a Stage IV woman who never underestimates how a positive attitude will make my days better, but who is also realistic about my cancer, my life, and my death.

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2010 08:10AM YamaMama wrote: Hi Jenny, I'm an RN also and was diagnosed almost one year ago. First I just want to say that if a nurse told you you should be palliative care only you should report her. And forget immediately what she said. YOU are the only one that can make that decision. It's your call whether you want to be treated aggressively or not. It's your body. You make the decisions after your docs tell you what options you have. I know it feels like you need to rush to make decisions, but take a deep breath, and know that you have so much support right here along with a wealth of information from women who know first hand what the latest treatments are. And definitely go for the anxiety meds, and sleep meds too if you aren't sleeping.

Posts.Title: Now I now how to do it...some wedding pics! ElaineD nancyh

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2012 12:10PM YamaMama wrote: I was diagnosed Stage IV from initial diagnosis just over 3 years ago with mets to the bone, and liver.  I was started on Tamoxifen, and after 6 months was NED.  I had a bilateral mastectomy with reconstruction and remained NED until this past September when my PET showed bone only progression in my femurs, spine and hips.  I did have to have some rads to my left femur for pain relief. And I switched to Arimidex.  Three months ago my PET was looking better.  I recently had my ovaries out, and I feel that my next PET in a few weeks will look even better.  My onc also won't answer those questions, but has told me from day one, to prepare for the worst, but to expect the best.  I try to remember that.  I also think being my own best advocate and being aware of my options has helped me.  Though I seldom post, I read what others post often.
Posts.Title: Expected Life SPAMgirl jocanuck1951

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2010 12:07PM YamaMama wrote: The women here put things in such perspective. I work in a completely different field of nursing, and though I am learning more than I want to about oncology, in all the wrong ways, I know it will help me not only personally with my own health, but in my work. Because of this thread I've read more about palliative care, and can see more clearly myself what it's all about. I know that when the day comes that I hear that term in regards to myself I might not panic as much. Jenny, I know the shock of this diagnosis is terrible. I was told once that having stage IV is like having a radio on constantly in every room you're in. Sometimes the music is so loud it's overwhelming. Other times it's in the background and you can barely hear it. But it's always there. I hope the music gets turned down low for you soon.

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2012 07:03PM YamaMama wrote: Diana, Please get your doc to give you a pain med that you take around the clock.  Take your pain meds even if you do NOT have pain.  Pain is like a snowball rolling downhill.  The longer it rolls, the bigger it gets, and the harder it is to slow down.  If you take something when you have small amounts of pain, it's much easier to control, and to keep controlled.   When your pain has been in control for a while (weeks, months, whatever a while is for you) then you can play with the doses maybe lower them slowly to see what you can tolerate.  But first and foremost, for the best quality of living day to day, you should get pain relief.  There are so many options available, there is absolutely no reason for anyone to have to live with pain.  If your onc is unable to get your pain under control ask for a Pain Medicine consult. Please let us know how you're doing. Best wishes....

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2012 07:10AM YamaMama wrote: effcancer, Yesterday, I saw my onc, and he gave me my new options since my progression.  Afinitor is one of those options, and I am afraid of that threshold. Literally two hours later, we sat in my husband's onc's office and my husband was then admitted to the hospital. He is very ill, and I am afraid of the doorways. Right now, that doorway opens to a spiral staircase down, it's dark, I can't see, and one mis-step and I'm going to fall.  Thank you, because I needed to read your post today. I am courageous. And if I say that often enough I will believe it. I hope.

Posts.Title: phobia needing help hezzy dreamwriter

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2010 12:40PM YamaMama wrote: Last night we were at a social function and there were a lot of my mother's friends there. They had not seen me since my diagnosis. I knew my mother had told them and that was fine, but I was braced for the hugs, the "oh you look wonderful". "I can't even tell you're sick" comments. What I wasn't braced for was the woman who sat next to me and said "we have to be strong, don't we". "I don't like to talk to your mom about it because it makes her cry, but how are you?". And the kicker..."I'm 17 years out from mine, so I know exactly what you're going through, and I'm just fine now". But she didn't. And I just wanted to go home and hide at that point. It somewhat ruined my evening for me. But I had to act like all was ok, so it didn't ruin the evening for the rest of my family. People just don't stop to think do they...

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2010 01:57AM YamaMama wrote: Hi Daisy, I was stage IV from the get go and was completely blown away by the news, because I had no symptoms other than a less than one cm lump in my breast. I had the PET scan that showed one mets to my liver and one to my femur.  I did have a liver biopsy which confirmed mets, and it wasn't too bad. They nurse will give you a med that will make you pretty much doze through the procedure and I also got some versed which has a amnesia effect, so I did forget alot of it afterwards.                                              I was put on Tamoxifen and did have some progression in my bones, but am in remission now. I also get zometa, and zoladex. May 1st is my one year anniversary since that fateful mammogram. I agree with the others who suggest meds for anxiety, and depression. I hope your biopsy is negative for mets, and that this is something else that is easy to deal with.  Please feel free to private message me. I know this waiting thing stinks. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Initial diagnosis of stage IV? daisylego redskies

Posts.Content: May 10, 2010 08:25PM YamaMama wrote: Hi Sue, Tamoxifen, Zoladex, and Zometa for me for a year now. I did have a bilateral mastectomy, and radiation this past Nov. I had only one small mets to the bone and one small mets to the liver at the beginning. I did have a bit of progression in the bone, but as of about a month ago I am NED. So, hang in there. It took a while for me, and I know everyone has different results.

Posts.Title: PHILLY CONFERENCE and a dinner heatherpalmerton AliceJean

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2013 03:00AM YamaMama wrote: Renae, I was diagnosed with mets to bones and liver almost 4 years ago. My dear sweet wonderful husband, my love, best friend, and greatest supporter was diagnosed with leukemia one and a half years ago. He made it through a stem cell transplant and went into a remarkable remission.  He was doing great and then started having trouble breathing.  In September after a three short weeks in the hospital he died.  Some of the last things he said to me was that he wanted me to live. He wanted me enjoy every moment I could. He made me promise to go on, continue loving my family, and also to continue working. I struggle every day to stay in the moment. But it is crucial for me. It is crucial for my family.  I struggle with being here after almost 4 years and my husband's illness was short in comparison. Why is he gone? Why am I still here? So many questions. The reality is I will never know the answers.  Life is not always fair.  My onc said to me last week, that after so many years of treating people with cancer he still has no idea as to why bad things happen to good people. They just do. It is a conscious decision to find joy in each day. To surround myself with people that make me smile, that love me and bring positive energy to my day. I am not always successful. I have bad moments, and  bad days. But I like I said...it's a conscious decision. It's gotten easier with practice. Journaling has helped me. I journal about the bad times. But when I journal about the good things it really does help. I have had some days when the only good thing that happened was that I got up that morning. Or that my day at work was done, or that I got to speak to a precious grandchild on the phone.  But those little things...will someday be the big things.  Sleep is another big one. I always feel worse, more sad, more scared, when I haven't slept.  Ambien is my friend on those nights.  Take care of yourself.  A day at a time, and today is the only day to deal with right now.

Posts.Content: YamaMama wrote: My last two PET scans have been NED for bone and liver mets. But a small area showed up in my colon which was removed during a colonoscopy and proved not to be breast mets, but a new primary colon cancer. I'm currently waiting to see if I'm going to need surgery for this or if the colonoscopy was enough to take care of it.  My docs have asked me about genetic testing in the past and so far I haven't done it. But now especially with this new diagnosis of a second cancer I'm considering it. I have children and want to be proactive for them. I'm wondering if anyone has any info to share about it? Pros and Cons? It's an expense I have no problem with as long as it will only help my children. Dx 5/1/2009, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Genetic testing? YamaMama YamaMama

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2010 07:38AM YamaMama wrote: Thank you all for your input. This is actually my third cancer. I had melanoma found very early and removed about 15 years ago, then stage iv breast ca, and now colon ca. I am the only one in my family with any kind of cancer so I guess I've just hit the mother load and hopefully no one else has to go through this. I would like to have the testing done. My children are grown and either have families or are in the process of trying to have thier own children. Other than my fear that I have passed my cancer genetics on to them, I am most concerned about the implications (ie; future insurance coverages, life insurance etc...for them).  My docs are trying to tell me that with the new health care laws, my children will not be penalized due to pre-existing conditions. My children have already started screening due to having wonderful docs. And though my youngest daughter's insurance wouldn't pay for a mammogram because she is only 24 it did pay for a breast ultra sound which picked up a benign lump this past year.  So, I'm glad they are being proactive. As for the cost of the test, as long as there are no penalties for my children long term for having the test I'm all for it and I'll have it done even if I have to pay part of the cost. I'll be meeting with a genetics counselor after the holidays to discuss the details, but knew I'd gain some insight from you all here. Thanks again to all.

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2009 03:54PM YamaMama wrote: Tracy,  I have mets to the bone and liver, not the lung. But as a woman having BC and also I am a nurse, I can tell you that I think you should follow up on the lung shadow. If you are concerned, and you wouldn't ask if you weren't, then that's enough to warrant further eval. I really think you should ask your doc to refer you to a pulmonologist for evaluation. If only to give you peace of mind. You may have just had a touch of the flu or something that day...but...if you are worried, get it checked out, so you can relax about it. Best wishes for some peace of mind...
Posts.Title: BC and trouble breathing tracy603 YamaMama

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2012 09:33PM YamaMama wrote: Luke & Jesse's Mom, I'm dealing with the same thing.  My last scan showed decrease in number of lesions, and decrease intensity of some of them.  I also have some in my femurs.  I had rads to my left femur in December, and that pain has been relieved.  My spine however has really never bothered me.  Now at night it aches. My husband says I yell out when I turn in my sleep.  And it has woken me up.  Really no discomfort in my back during the day unless I'm sitting in my office for long periods of time.  I find if I get up and walk it helps.  I had my ovaries out about 8 weeks ago.  I had hoped that would help....Pet scan on Monday. Vicodin does not seem to help my discomfort either. You'll be in my thoughts and prayers.

Our son in law is there for the week doing repair on downed lines.  So, I'm glad you're doing well and staying warm! I'm just reading, watching a few movies, and of course I'm online too.  And tonight is the super bowl. I really don't watch football, but my husband does, and that's what will be on the tv tonight.
